I am - as you’d might expect - arriving slowly but firmly towards the end of my tether on this issue. 

Foreign and Commonwealth veterans are not cash machines for the Home Office, Health department or anyone else. They’ve done their bit; Secretaries of State must do theirs.

To be clear- this bill is still due, and the veteran must pay it to Government, or face enforcement action. 

Whilst Home Office policies lead to situations like this, I’m afraid I won’t be voting for the Home Secretary’s latest ‘Immigration and Borders’ bill tomorrow.

Following our efforts to remove visa fees for F&C personnel, a fresh demand for payment of a £36k NHS bill for a brain tumour issued to a Fijian veteran last week classing him an ‘illegal immigrant’ at the time of the op. He now has ILR - thanks to @Cit4Sol, but seriously? 🤯 https://t.co/MNL7A7fXfw

"I have huge sympathy for that. The facts are the vast majority get a test in time, but that's no good if you're one of those people and we need to make sure the test and trace system is fit for purpose in Plymouth, and I'll continue to redouble my efforts.”

“Testing has been very difficult. I have huge sympathy for the hundreds of people I've spoken to in Plymouth who have driven past Seaton Barracks and seen it empty, whilst being unable to get a test and therefore can't return to work or their children return to school.”

“Of course afterwards there will be a kind of review into what's gone on and that's the time to think about what we could've done better, but I think we all need to put our shoulders to the wheel and deal with any second wave, which it looks like we're at the beginning of."
